segments.text: What is some of your personal background with trains?
I never worked for a railroad, but I've been interested in railroads, so I would have to know what a plane was.
As a small child, I could go out in my front yard and see several railroads about a block and a half away from where I lived.
So I just grew up waving at the great engineer.
And I have never lost my interest.
I'm interested in various facets of railroad history, but not exclusively history.
I'm interested in the current activities and the future of the industry.
photographing trains, doing research on history.
I have written several articles on history.
You're a member of the National Railway Historical Society?
That is correct.
What is this organization?
The National Railway Historical Society is a nationwide group of people who investigate railways.
The people in the society are interested in all facets of it.
Some are interested in diesel, some are interested in steam locomotives, and others are passionate friends of electric and urban railways.
But we all have a common interest in railroads.
So we all want this large society, which has a hundred and so many chapters in different cities throughout the United States.
And Houston has one, too.
Houston has one, too, that's correct.
How large is the chapter in Houston?
The chapter has approximately one and a half members.
Are they all active members?
I would say about half of them are active.
Okay.
What are some of the activities that you do?
The Gulf Coast Chapter has our own several river parks.
We have the Good Cheer, which is the Kansas City Southern, or the Palma King City Southern Lounge, our population park.
We have the Verde Valley, which is the Farmer's Center Park.
We have a sleeping car.
We have a chair car, which is a former Texas Sub-Civic, 1141.
We have a baggage RPO car, which is a former Santa Fe 3401.
We have a baggage car, which LeBron McDonald donated to us, which he recently spoke to me about in Seattle.
We recently acquired a wooden boot from an individual that formerly belonged to the Compton Railway.
And a few months ago, we obtained a horse car in the same place.
How did you describe that?
A horse car.
At one time, horses were shipped by rail.
So I bid race horses for Compton.
A special railway passenger car set up these horses.
The exterior is generally like a large baggage car, but they have indoors.
They carry horses, and they have individual stalls for the animals and facilities for the hay.
They feed and kill the animals as well as for the caretakers as well.
I see, okay.
Well, about what era are these cars from?
The equipment that we have dates from about 1915.
the baggage car and the most recent one was the 1940s.
Okay, so I guess that around 1920 was the height of the passenger service in America.
The height of passenger service was in the 20s before automobiles became very popular.
Everybody had one in his garage before the roads really improved.
They were probably the peak number of passenger trains operating during the 1920s.
What were the main lines
Did they just go across the country, or were they basically interstate?
Well, there were a number of transcontinental lines.
Houston was on the slow Pacific transcontinental route, known as the Sunset Route, which ran through New Orleans and Los Angeles.
We were also on the New York City route, which made Houston the Midwest, the San Luis, the Burlington.
through that's connected to Colorado.
Again, the Midwest area.
The KD basically had local services.
But in addition to these through routes, there were a number of local.
There used to be a rail car that went from Houston to the Port.
It was a lot of service to Galveston.
before they improved highways and roads, really went after the gallows business.
They really competed with each other, and they were really righteous here to get to Gallows.
They were the quickest.
There were a lot of branches in East Texas that had either what we call gas-electric cars, which are one-car trains, or even next trains.
Just a .
And throughout West Texas, Midwest, there were a lot of these little branch lines.
The rail passenger service only connected large cities with large cities.
It connected small-town America with large cities and small-town America with small-town America.
People would ride at one or two stations down the line to get into railways.
How would you describe some of the services offered?
Did most people spend the night on the train?
Did they have dining cars?
At the height of passenger service,
I would think that, I believe that most of the people rode the local, the daytime local trains.
People who had more affluence rode the main trains of the day.
Cheap, you know, 20th century men did.
The sons of men did at that time.
These trains had all sorts of amenities.
They had sleeping cars.
They had dining cars, house cars.
They had barber shops.
There were libraries that were in the trains.
So they really were a rolling resource.
But we also need to remember that we, today, may not think of them to be very comfortable, since they didn't have air conditioning on the way to the crew of the equipment.
They had open windows, and they deterred the singers and the co-workers from reporting to the train.
These were basically steam engines at that time?
They were basically steam locomotives at that time.
There were a few railroads in use that were electrified.
Houston had a local commuter system downtown.
Streetcars?
Streetcars.
When did they phase out?
They began disappearing in the late 20s and early 30s, and the last streetcar ran in 1940.
One of the problems was that.
West Street cars, these ones growing, cost them much to lighten the track.
It was so much quicker to extend the bus lines out.
Plus, once the streetcar company converted the buses, they no longer had to pay them anything for the streets, which they did when they had rails in the street.
So they had all sorts of incentives to do away with the streetcar and replace them with buses.
Well, what were the main cities that were served by the cross-country lines?
Well, there were certain gateway cities, Chicago, St. Louis, Memphis, New Orleans.
Trains normally did not run through these cities.
For example, you would have New York and Chicago connected with a train.
And once you got to Chicago, you could change trains and get on.
If you were going to Los Angeles, you could get on the Santa Fe, go up to Los Angeles.
Or if you were going to the city northwest, you could change to the Burlington and go out to the Twin Cities.
They were basically through trains from Chicago, say, to places like Seattle, Los Angeles, San Francisco, that you could travel without change.
But you always had to change in Chicago, in St. Louis, in Memphis, in New Orleans.
There were, on occasion, through cars that went through these cities.
But by and large, they were few and far between.
Well, I imagine that the train rides across country were very popular and probably the only mode of transportation across the country.
That's true.
As I said, the roads were not improved, not only up there, but long on the trip of endurance.
The airlines were just getting started, and they were fine.
You would hear it when you grew up in a single-engine airplane.
But to travel at all across country, you went by rail.
Okay.
What were the typical people that were on the trains at East Town?
Were they the businessmen, or were they families traveling?
Well, they really were a cross-section of the population.
They had business travel.
They had the very affluent business travel.
Some people owned their own cars at that time, and they would attach them to the planes and travel across the country.
There was traveling salesmen there who used trains to go from city to city with all their wares.
people going on vacations.
The railroads really helped promote travel and tourism in the United States.
They helped promote the National Park.
I won't give any credit for the start of the National Park, but there were areas of the country like Yellowstone, which the railroads really promoted.
It got other people interested in the great national heritage.
What was the public attitude towards trains?
Did people see them as a thing of the future or just a fad?
Well, in the 20s, railroads were an old, established industry.
It started in the United States in the 1920s.
They'd been around for 90-plus years.
And they were a big business, and they were very noticeable.
Everybody had to use trains.
But they had a problem.
They had a run-in with somebody who worked for the railroad company.
Everybody at that time knew someone who worked for the railroad.
They were probably the largest employers in most of the cities across the country.
How would you contrast that with the late 50s and the 60s?
All right.
By the late 50s, we talked about the depression and the war.
And a lot of things have changed.
We have an interstate system, the highway system being developed.
The airline industry has come of age.
We've gone from the single-engine prop planes to the seven-engine DC-8s.
And people were more interested in flexibility.
They didn't want to be tied to the railroad schedule.
When you took the train, you had to go in the train room.
You hopped in the elevator.
You could go when you wanted to go.
You could stop when you wanted to go, when you didn't want to stop.
like any size that you wanted.
Oh, a matter of convenience.
A matter of convenience.
How about the prices?
Is that comparable to an automobile trip across the country, or was it higher?
Well, that's another thing.
If a family was traveling across the country in an automobile, it didn't cost any more to travel in the car than if you put four people in there and put one person in the car.
Obviously, the food was a little more, and your hotel may cost you a little more.
The travel didn't cost you anything.
Railroad train you had to buy a ticket for everybody.

Even with so-called family fairs, where one person would pay for a fare, and then the wife would go for a fare, and the children would go for a partial fare, they still would cost them much more than driving.
What role did the trains play in World War II?
During World War II, the railroads were very important.
In fact, they held most of the intercity passengers.
And most of the troops that moved to the United States moved by mail.
In the time between, it was very crowded.
It was very difficult to get a seat, very difficult to get a filming space.
The military, the government had first choice of all the accommodation.
But with people having money in the home front again, after the Depression, people had money to spend.
They did do a little personal travel, even during the war.
between 1936 and 1966 say what were some of the improvements in the rail system all right beginning in the early 30s the railroad began converting
First of all, the dining cars, and then the sleeping cars, and the more modern chair cars into air conditioning equipment.
That was probably the biggest innovation that made travel comfortable.
Keep the windows closed, didn't have the dust, didn't have to bother with an open window.
At the same time, the new technologies were coming into play.
The digital locomotive appeared on the scene.
forward-thinking people began developing lightweight trucks, the Pacific Railroad for one, the Burlington for another.
It's a lightweight train.
A lightweight train makes use of modern stainless steel and other lighter-weight steels, which have high strength.
They probably weighed about two-thirds that of an older conventional type of
comparable type piece of equipment.
What were those made of?
Those were made of steel from about 1912 on.
Before that, they were mostly wood.
They were steel underframes.
By the 30s, most of the older wooden equipment had been scrapped and smoked to steel.
What about the advances in competing industries at this time?
The air service?
The air service in Peru, quite a bit.
The jet airplane really made their travel.
It was relatively quiet and comfortable compared to the piston airplanes, and they were quick.
A person could make a business trip almost cross-country, transact business, and by stretch you could be back home that evening.
But a two-day trip out to the coast and back with, then the realm of possibility, whether you went by rail or it would take you a week to get there and back.
So the business travel disordered the railways fairly quickly when the jet airplanes came in.
And when business travel disordered, that meant a lot of the first-class passengers, so the first class, in this case, being the sleeping car passengers.
So the sleeping car business was the first part of the rail passenger service that really saw the effect of the airlines.
What was the role of the black American?
In the 1960s, it was basically when the civil rights movement took all its strength.
And how are blacks treated as employees and as passengers?
All right.
We have some separate country on the Old South and the North and the West.
The Old South, including Texas, where the Jim Crow laws were quite separate.
cars or accommodations for the black passengers and the white passengers.
In most cases, this meant a separate coach or a sectioned coach where the blacks were in one half of the car and the whites in the other half.
As far as sleeping cars were concerned, blacks were allowed into sleeping cars.
But as a matter of course, very few had enough money to travel in sleeping cars, so they were up in the segregated coaches.
As far as employees were going, the block employees were kept in the lower rungs of the employee hierarchy.
For example, they were never in locomotives in the air, but they were frequently locomotified, and that's as far as they could look to aspire.
They could become porters on a small passenger train, but they couldn't become break-ins and conductors.
Were they kicks in the dining cars?
They were kicks in the dining cars.
They were waiters in the dining cars.
By and large, the speaking car porters were all black.
Okay.
But the speaking car conductors were all white.
Were the baggage handlers employed by the individual lines?
The baggage handlers were employed by the individual railroads.
Okay.
Were they black, too?
Yes, they were black baggage handlers.
Okay.
Do the blacks tend to ride those trains often?
Blacks were a very good sign to El Dorado.
They stuck with it longer than most of the white population.
I think it's a matter of the economics.
They didn't have cars or they didn't have...
They tend on to take them from Atlanta to New York or something.
They were passionate things.
What's the difference in the black situation in the south and in the north as opposed to the Washington state?
The accommodations were great.
In the north?
In the north, they were not.
I see.
Even in the south, the stations had different ways to get to places.
But not in the north?
Not in the north.
Okay.
What was the public attitude in the mid-'60s and early-'70s as rail travel declined?
Well, most of them didn't care less, so they didn't take the train.
But there was a handful of people
And some of them didn't travel very often either, I must admit.
It was protest every time I was at a road point to take a train off.
There was labor union that didn't want to take trains off, so that reduced the amount of employment available for their people.
And all the small town mayors didn't want to take the trains off, even though their people may not use the trains.
In fact, they had a train coming through town for the matter of a local price.
Did it help increase tourism also?
In some areas it was.
It did increase tourism, but the tourist planes really have continued to run.
The Rio Grande Railroad only joined in last year.
They ran their own private passenger plane from 1971 to 1983, and it ran for almost every trip.
But even at that level, they lost money on it.
Let's talk about Amtrak for a minute, then, since you mentioned it.
What is Amtrak?
Amtrak is a public corporation set up by the U.S. Congress, the National Railroad Passion Corporation, to operate the railroad passion trains in the United States.
In the late 1960s, a lot of the trains disappeared and a lot of the trains that were remaining
were down to a strip of coaches only, maybe one coach and a man full of baggage cars, and they made all the stops, and people had to wait on the baggage express.
And the Amtrak was set up or organized to be a nationwide passenger train network.
The railroads had the option of joining or not joining Amtrak.
If they joined Amtrak, they had to buy into the corporation, which was
I don't remember the exact figure, but it was so many years past the deficit that they had to incur a huge amount of money that they had to pay to join.
Once they joined Amtrak, they were relieved of any obligation to run the passenger service.
Three railroads, or actually four railroads opted not to join Amtrak.
One of them was the southern, one of them was the Rio Grande, as I mentioned.
Rock Island.
Rock Island was the third one, because they really didn't have the money to join.
And the fourth one was the Georgia Railroad, which only ran a mixed freight on its system.
Oh, okay.
Well, what were the circumstances leading up to that?
Was it basically the economy?
It wasn't the economy as such.

It was the fact that, as I say, these competing modes of transportation, primarily the private automobile, but to a large extent the jet aircraft, had taken most of the passengers away from the railroads.
A lot of people say the railroads didn't thrive, but I disagree with that.
After the Second World War, the railroads re-equipped all their big trains, and they were buying new types of equipment up until the mid and late 50s, which told me they were fine.
At that time, a piece of equipment would cost $100,000 to $300,000 a car, and they were spending millions and millions and millions of dollars to re-equip their trains, which was pithy.
And they really did.
And there were a number of trained even in 1971.
They're still all spit and polish.
But there were also a number that said, we're losing too much money on this.
And the way we minimize our loss is to do away with some dining car service.
We do away with car service.
And we just run this train back and forth.
I coach on it.
Did Amtrak reinstate the dining car service?
No.
When Amtrak came into effect on May 1, 1971,
Actually, about two-thirds of the fashion trains in the United States would just continue that day.
But Amtrak didn't want to take them over because they were losing too much money.
And that's one thing the railroads have complained about federally, is the fact that they had to buy into Amtrak.
The various regulatory commissions would not let them take off the trains they wanted to take off.
And yet Amtrak, being a national corporation, they became an operating company for the passenger service, discontinued virtually every train, but the railroad one discontinued.
What happened to the employees that were working for the trains that were discontinued?
Well, by and large, most, all of us were railroad employees, and some of them went with Amtrak.
the sleeping car people, the dining car people, the ticket office personnel, and so forth, had this option of either continuing to work for the railroad or sign up for landfills.
And in some cases, they continued to work for the railroad, and the railroad would build landfills for their salaries.
But with all the trains that discontinued, the railroad worked on a strict seniority system, so it was bumping down the line, so there weren't enough work for them.
for the last engineer on the seniority roster, and he didn't get to work.
So the same thing happened elsewhere.
They unfortunately allowed it.
Trains that were taken off, and a lot of railroads that took off trains or train tracks, especially in the dining car personnel.
And I think they made certain decisions.
There was a big discrimination set up recently, I think, in the film from Northern about a lot of people
were offered relatively low-status jobs.
Unfortunately, they really weren't qualified to do much else.
But the 1970s and 80s would be a little different.
The 1950s and 60s would be looking at how people treated.
Well, what was the...
What happened to the lines that had both passenger and freight service?
Did they just replace the passenger service that was now gone with their freight service?
Well, there are only one or two lines in the United States where there's more passenger and freight service.
And these trains that were discontinued when Amtrak took over, they just were off the railroad, and the railroad kept this line for freight service.
There's been a lot of changes since that.
We've had the Rock Island bankruptcy and this dismemberment.
We've had the Milwaukee railroad abandoned, all this western lines, and a couple other railroads that were abandoned, big pieces.
So there's been, we've had a, shake you out is not the right word, but a rationalization of the railroad system in the United States in the last 20 years.
And so the railroads that are left are much stronger
because the traffic that used to move over these marginal lines are now abandoned, are now moving over the remaining railroads.
Plus, with the Stigers Act, you know, earlier when I said these railroad freight rates are going to be wet-dated in the last several years.
Now the railroads, after being completely regulated in the right since the 1880s,
For the first time, we're able to go out and set rates to get track business to be competitive with truck lines, barge lines, and so on.
And they have gathered a lot of traffic back on their lines.
And I have been impressed myself.
There are a lot of people that are older, I mean, we're older than you think.
Not my age.
Who haven't changed over, but...
The railroad department has a lot of bright young people in recent years.
They've become very innovative in their way of traffic.
They've captured a lot of the business back that they used to have in most of the trucks.
They hope to get more coverage back.
Things such as land bridges, the road railer service that we had back in the spring.
A road railer is a combination of a highway trailer,
railroad freight car.
It has rubber tires for using on the highways and has small railroad wheels, which we put down on some track and had a couple together, and it's dedicated trains of road railers.

And all you have to do when you get to a town or you need to cut out a trailer to take that one off the train and it's ready to go, it would be a shipper or it was, of course, I practice, it doesn't have to be on the railroad.
I see.
Another recent innovation we've had here in Houston, between Houston and Dallas, is what DeSoto City calls its unofficial sprint trains.
This is a piggyback train or container train that handles only 15 cars or 30 trailers.
It runs overnight between Houston and Dallas.
But for the two-man crew, the same two people run the entire
run through eastern Dallas.
Now, a normal freight train run through eastern Dallas requires three crews because of the old seniority districts.
These two people now take 30 trailers back and forth through eastern Dallas.
Whatever it takes.
Before the railroad in the union made this route, it would have previously taken 15 people to handle the same amount of traffic.
Okay, hold on, I'll switch this over.
